Colony consists of a loose, branching tuft of reddish-brown stalks, each consisting of an alternating chain of zooecia. Easily mistaken for a red seaweed.

When examined closely, each branch consists of a double row of elongate zooecia, arranged in an overlapping chain. The outer corners of the zooecia have sharp corners, but lack terminal spines (unlike the similar Viridentula dentata). The ovicells (reproductive cells) are oval and pearly and the colony lacks beak-like avicularia. When extended, the lophophores are white and have 23-24 tentacles.
Individual zooecia about 0.5 mm long, colonies typically 5 but up to 10 cm tall.

Global: Cosmopolitan except in polar seas. Currently though to be of European origin and to have been distributed around the world by shipping, but recent research suggest this may be a complex of at least 3 regional species, although these can currently only be distinguished by molecular methods.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to Durban, especially in harbours.

Common introduced fouling species, found on the walls of gullies and other vertical surfaces, as well as on ships hulls, pilings and jetties in harbours. Often grows on the surfaces of large algae or on other bryozoans.

Well-known as a source of a group of bioactive chemical compounds called bryostatins, which have potential for the treatment of cancer, Alzheimer’s Disease and HIV/AIDS. These now appear in fact to be produced by a symbiotic bacteria Candidatus endobugula, rather than by the bryozoan itself.

All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.

Zooids are hermaphrodite, first being female and later male. Sperm liberated by males are drawn into female zooids, where they fertilise the eggs. The eggs are brooded and at this stage the zooids develop a rounded cap and are known as ovicells. Once liberated, the larvae have a short larval life before settling to establish new colonies. Existing colonies expand by budding new zooecia at the tips of the branches.

The distinctive colour and absence of protective avicularia can be used to separate this from related species. The Blue dentate moss-animal Viridentula dentata is blue and Bugulina colonies are orange or straw coloured and both bear avicularia.
